content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy R{R} because I am comfortable taking risks. Given the payoff structure, it seems that if my opponent is also risk-taking like me, we both will benefit significantly by choosing R (45$ each) in most of the 75 rounds. However, there's still a chance that we could end up with zero or 20$ each when we choose different strategies. Since I am more focused on gaining higher rewards and less concerned about potential losses, I would lean toward R. Plus, the overall payoff for choosing R is greater than B, even if I consider the worst-case scenario where my opponent always chooses B (40$ in 25 rounds and 0$ in the rest). This strategy maximizes my earnings on average over the course of the game.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, both me and my opponent have chosen R in the previous round, so our payoffs were 45$ each. For the next round, I would again choose strategy R{R}. By doing so, I hope that we will continue to get the maximum reward of 45$ if we both keep choosing R, as it appears to be beneficial for us given the payoff structure. However, there's still a slight chance that my opponent may switch their strategy in response to my previous choice. If they do, our future payoffs could change accordingly. But since I am more focused on maximizing my earnings in the long run by consistently choosing R, I will stick with my chosen strategy for now.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, I chose R while my opponent chose B in the previous round, so I received 0$ and they got 40$. For the next round, given my desire to maximize my earnings over the long run, I would switch my strategy to B{B} to hopefully get a positive payoff. By doing so, if my opponent continues with their strategy of choosing R, I will earn 20$ in this round, which is better than the 0$ I received earlier when both of us chose different strategies.

However, there's always a chance that my opponent may also switch their strategy to B in response to my previous choice, and if we both choose B, our payoffs will be 20$ each instead of 40$. But switching strategies now gives me an opportunity to earn at least some reward in this round, and if my opponent continues with R in the future, I can potentially get a higher payoff by choosing R again.

Overall, switching strategies from R to B allows me to hedge against potential losses and improve my chances of getting positive payoffs in the short term, while still hoping for maximum rewards in the long run if both of us continue to choose R most of the time.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

But sticking with B allows me to keep the higher reward I earned in this round while hoping for even higher rewards in the future if both of us continue to choose B.

Overall, choosing B provides me with an immediate high reward, and by sticking with it, I can potentially maintain a positive payoff trend over the long run if my opponent follows suit or switches strategies unpredictably.
